WorkItem.ClosedComment: It's completely different in 2.3.3, no more negative values.
WorkItem.Description:
Loading my resto druid (Teors@Jubei'Thos) into 2.3.2, it reports that:
 
HealBurst = -122.9695
HealSustained = -5358.782
 
Given that my healing isn't actually damaging players, I'm assuming there's something not quite right with the calculations... though looking at the new options, presumably this is a consequence: the defaults (which I haven't changed) are:
 
Single Target Max Healing Target: 9000 hps
Sustained Healing Target: 8500 hps
 
My gear clearly isn't up to that; perhaps a better indication of being to unable to meet the targets would be better than reporting a negative result of the simulation. Also, perhaps reasonable defaults would be better, though these targets are obviously going to scale up based upon the difficulty of the content. The raid healing I've sent (ToTC-10/25 normal modes) tends to be around 2-5K hps (average for a given encounter).

Comments.Message:
HealSustained and HealBurst are values that indicate whether you're behind or ahead of your target. I should have clarified this on that tab, I think. A negative value means you are short of your target. A positive value means you're ahead of your target. If you use the sliders to make both values match eachother, then you indicate that the current balance between burst and sustained is OK with you. If you manage to get them such that both values are 0 then you reached the current estimated HPS by the model.

Yes, your raid healing is usually much less. In "real" situations you have lag and lots of overhealing and all those tiny mistakes (such has HOT clipping) that make it go down. We're talking about theoretical hps here :)

I hope these answers satisfy your query. If not, just reply.
That should be written in the Modules Notes, confused me too
